>> I am Tom Gama, one of the co-founders of
Central Interactive, and we recently
released Claros Expedition 33 on the PC,
PS5, and Xbox.
>> For those who come after,
>> right? Everything started as a patient
project from my friend Guom. There was
already a love for writing on his side
and content creation and me on the
technical side when I started to helping
you know from time to time just on some
small gameplay features here and there
and then it grew bigger. We had like a
creative team being assembled and then
we did a vertical slice with a bigger
team. It kept growing and we signed with
our publisher and the team just kept
growing and we went on to release
claroscer expedition 33 [music] and it
was an amazing journey for us
throughout.
The very very first time I explored
Unreal Engine was actually Unreal Engine
one a long time ago. I was uh playing
with a map editor from Dusx. took many
years before I actually dive into
creating my own uh game. Overall, the
community is very dedicated to Unreal.
You can really tell that there is like a
love almost for for the engine and I
think it really shows in the way people
are sharing the knowledge like there is
no big secret to keep. It's very open,
very positive.
I think the main way the structure of
the engine helped us grow and deliver
this project [music] in the end. It
started really early when it was only Gu
and myself because GM is not a
programmer. It was important to not
prevent him from, you know, working on
the project. If I were to do a feature,
it had to be done in blueprints because
I couldn't humanly, you know, do
everything on my own on the gameplay
side. GM was always like a big
contributor. We have a ton of blueprints
and all the core logic of the game
actually ended up uh being blueprints
even features entirely made by
programmers. It was a faster way for us
to try to innovate on the gameplay
instead of trying to innovate, you know,
on some heavy technical stuff that we
just didn't have the manpower. And as we
moved forward and the team grew,
everybody was blueprint fluent, so so to
speak, and they would contribute
directly in the core logic. Everybody
had a lot of freedom to do their job.
thanks to that particular tool. I think
the other one we used a lot was a
sequencer because everything almost in
the game during battle in particular are
level sequences. As soon as you have a
level sequence playing the game
designers, the VFX artists, sound
designers, all the locations or
everything they need to, you know, put
projectiles or put VFX and animate all
of that also everything can be, you
know, perfectly in sync. And I think it
was a huge vector of autonomy and
creativity for everybody in the team.
When we started developing expedition
33, it was still Unreal 4 at the time,
but the engine was always writing, you
know, an update. So, okay, here comes
the world partition. Having that
technology was good for us, both in
terms of performance, but also just
workflow as a team. And then of course,
Lummen and the night. At the time, we
were trying to figure out the right
quality settings for our shadows. And
same for Nite. create all the levels of
LODs manually. As a small team, you
don't have, you know, all the resources
to do that properly. Having nit [snorts]
made artist life much simpler. So
[music] for us, it was the perfect
alignment of planets between Unreal and
our project, you know, making progress
at the same time. I think the most
important things when you are
considering which engine you're going to
use to to build your game is to see what
type of content they want to create. So
for example, the sequencer for us was
key because we knew we would have so
many cinematics and the characters would
be important. So if we were to choose an
engine today, Metauman of course would
be, you know, one of the key factors
pushing ourselves toward Unreal. The
important thing also is to look at the
whole ecosystem around the engine. You
have of course learning resources but
you [music] also have all the
marketplaces that are tied to the
different engines and in the case of Fab
for Unreal Engine for us it has [music]
been super useful to get some either
free or paid assets. It's usually a very
good starting point both for visuals but
also for some features. We do have some
features that we prototyped using some
of the plugins that were available on
the Fab marketplace. And then when we
decide that okay this is a cool feature
that fits into the game then we usually
make our own version you plug and play
you mix and match and it's also a great
creative tool basically to have this
whole pallet of available assets online.
We are really excited to see what will
be happening at the game awards because
there are so many you know other great
games running next to us like many of
them were you know actually looking up
to as a source of inspiration. Yeah, we
could have never imagined the amount of
success and love where we were getting
from all over [music] the world because
yeah, we received a lot of love as

which we put a lot of, you know, emotion
and a little bit piece of ourselves also
in it. [music] See that it brings
emotion to people. I think it's the most
